div1.fw:
MILDRED R. BENNETT
329 North Cedar
RED CLOUD, NEBRASKA
div1.p: Your good letter came this morning. Yes, I have a lovely letter from Mrs. Aly which I enclose for you to read.
It sounds as if you have a busy summer ahead. When you're in Lincoln will you see the lady who is a sensitive? Sometime, if she does not object, I'd like to go there with you.
Everyone at our place in fine - except I have a summer cold which seems very hard to eliminate. I have been as lazy as possible. Today I am at the Memorial as my regular hostess is out of town.
Your T.V. plans sound great. I will have to see them. I sent your records to my sister Norma and to a friend in New York. They were delightful - only wished there were more records.

When you are in Oregon you will
6
probably see Mrs. Aly. I will not say anything to her about the newspaper writings until you tell me to. Perhaps you'd rather talk to her first.
Mrs. Sherwood's daughter-in-law was to ask me to order her a Cycle. She was so pleased to meet you that she felt she must have the book. We have sold all we had so mist now re order
The men are starting to put up the lightning rod today. I hope it does protect the building from fire.
Have a good trip and take good care of yourself.

Many thanks for your letter of June 20. I have appreciated all your interest and assistance in my work, and I am delighted to hear about the ceremony in Nebraska. I wish I could have been there; it was a great experience for Dr. Neihardt, and I would specially like to have met you.

I am flattered that you want to read my dissertation. It is centered on rhetoric and oral interpretation, and consequently the biographical section is somewhat distorted, but the general organization of the biography will follow the rough outline of that part. I should welcome any suggestion you could make; this is tramendous material, and I want the biography to present as clear a picture of Dr. Neihardt as possible. Please do make any comment you have time to express to me; I shall value any suggestion.

The interest of the University of Nebraska Press in Dr. Neihardt's work is a very good sign. I am writing Virginia Faulkner because I have some ideas she may be interested in for republication of some of the less known writing. The Poetic Values lectures should certainly be reprinted, along with the unfinished one the originally was intended to be part of the series. I have been prodding Dr. Neihardt to write the third section he meant to add to it. If those three lectures, one other one the same general theme, and a new one could be put together, the book would be a full statement of Dr. Neihardt's poetic theory, and it ought to be done. The University of Missouri Press has such an idea, but nothing has come of it.

Did you know that I have a bust of Dr. Neihardt? It was made in 1948, also by Mrs. Neihardt, and it is a remarkable piece of work. It is larger than life--what Mrs. Neihardt called "heroic size." Eventually it, too, should be cast in bronze. The only other bust in existence is in one of the buildings at Wayne, and someone should work on getting it cast. It is a much younger portrait.
Again may I thank you for your nice letter and your many kindnesses. I shall hope to hear from you again, and eventually we are sure to meet. I shall look forward.

closer.signed:
Lucile F. Aly
Lucile F. Aly
